awd_titl_txt: Peer-Assisted Team Research (PATR): A Method for Early Undergraduate Research
awd_abstract_narration:
Undergraduate research is a high-impact practice that increases retention, fosters academic performance and scientific literacy, increases motivation to study science, and raises STEM graduation rates. This project will test an innovative, cost-effective method, Peer-Assisted Team Research (PATR) that will involve more students in undergraduate research experiences earlier in college, improving their scientific reasoning abilities and STEM self-efficacy. Trained peer leaders will supervise student teams as they design and conduct increasingly complex research studies on interdisciplinary topics. PATR students will master scientific reasoning and seeing themselves as "people who do science," becoming more motivated and taking more STEM courses. 

PATR is an adaptable template useful in a variety of institutional settings: general education and introductory major's courses, STEM classes without labs, and co-curricular activities such as science clubs. Brooklyn College is collaborating with four other branches of City University of New York to evaluate the effectiveness of the PATR method in a variety of settings. The project's intellectual merit resides in the method's grounding in proven STEM pedagogy and current cognitive research. The project's broader impacts stem from enabling more students to participate in undergraduate research experiences, thus fostering a well-trained, diverse work-force. PATR is an adaptable, scalable and cost-effective method that prepares students for faculty-mentored research. The project will generate data using behavioral assessment and standardized test instruments to determine if students participating in PATR are developing the higher-level abstract reasoning abilities required to plan and carry out research, compared with control students.

por.por_cntn:
Much research demonstrates that undergraduate research involvement in STEM improves academic outcomes, but often students who could benefit the most cannot secure placements within faculty labs. Peer-Assisted Team Research (PATR) is a flexible research experience model designed to include more undergraduates in research earlier in their academic careers in different STEM areas. PATR allows students to design and conduct increasingly complex interdisciplinary studies with a focus on the process of scientific research. Topics investigated thus far span a variety of scientific disciplines including biology, chemistry, physics and psychology. In terms of Intellectual Merit, the project was innovative in providing a new inexpensive and accessible method, based on what is already known about undergraduate research experiences, to involve undergraduate students in research early in their time in college. In terms of broader impacts, the PATRA method can be readily adapted and adopted to involve undergraduate students in research, including those from underrepresented groups. Our data showed that involvement increased students’ interest in continuing to do undergraduate research in more traditional settings. After participating in PATR, students were more likely to identify graduate school and research careers as goal after college.

The overall goals of Peer-Assisted Team Research (PATR) are to: 1. Improve scientific reasoning abilities for a diverse audience of both future STEM majors and non-majors; and  2. Foster the motivation and confidence to master STEM material, by increasing the opportunities for undergraduate research experiences, particularly during the first two years of college when there are relatively fewer opportunities for faculty-mentored research.

The PATR method is very versatile and the basic methods have been adapted for use in multiple institutional settings, including courses in general education, honors, and majors courses as well as various non-credit options. A PATR module includes: an engaging article from popular media; a professional article on the same topic read via a method to help visualize the experiment design; team-designed experiments and analysis; and discussions on broader applications. PATR students report a better understanding of the research process and increases in self-confidence as they complete more modules. PATR students see themselves as scientists, are motivated to take more STEM classes and to continue as participants in faculty research. We worked with other CUNY colleges and most recently with some high schools to test implementation strategies and expand and disseminate the cache of module topics so that others in different academic settings can adapt PATR for use.

We have tested the effectiveness of the PATR method with multiple PATR modules with more than 200 freshmen, sophomores, juniors, and seniors at multiple institutions, with many from groups under-represented in STEM. A number of students have done more than one PATR session, some as many as three or four. Results from surveys find students exhibiting markedly improved science-positive attitudes after taking part in PATR activities with this measure, increasing with the number of modules completed. Other changes with PATR participation included increased feelings of confidence in presenting in and discussing scientific topics with groups, and increased ability to critically read scientific writing and analyze data. Students expressed increased confidence in possessing the skills necessary to be a scientist or researcher, and greater interest and enthusiasm about science research careers. A high proportion of the students who took part in PATR continued to do more traditional undergraduate research with faculty during the academic year or summers. The junior and senior peer leaders who ran the PATR sessions also reported benefitting from taking part in PATR so they benefit as well.
